content: Well everyone, today we're trying something a little different. So, thank you to More Fun Studios and Arena Breakout Infinite for sponsoring the video. But rest assured, I'm going to tell you what I think. And it just so happens that I am pretty impressed. Now, I've actually been playing it for a few days, and there's a bunch of little bitty quality of life things that are really important in an extraction shooter, in my opinion, that they get right here. For one, it's free to play, meaning that you can just load in and try it for yourself to see if it's your type of game and if it feels good to you, which is important because this type of game is not for everybody. And if you want to play with your buddies or at least get them introduced to the genre or to this specific game now, they can just easily get into it. But even if you want to play it solo, there are solo modes, duos modes, and of course the kind of core trios mode, which the game is mostly built around. There's all sorts of little touches. Like for example, if I want to check how many rounds I have in my magazine, you'll notice it's not on the UI like on screen. But if I just go alt t, you actually check the magazine by hand. You can actually like physically check it. If I swap to my shotgun and check that way, you can see, okay, I've got about half left. Okay, so maybe this would be a time to reload if I had ammunition. And once you start reloading, it plays out in real time. And so you can't just play willy-nilly. You know, this is not like a light-hearted Call of Duty type shooter. This is much more hardcore and tactical, even down to something as small in detail as the ability to sway and lean around corners to peak it. Now, they have five different maps right now available for you to try. And they have different playlists and loadouts available for missions with all different modes, for highle play, for introductory play. They actually adjust the audio and uh audio balancing based on the equipment you have on, which is super super cool. Certain helmets, for example, have a visor that will literally limit your field of view. It's just really really carefully thought out and well executed if you ask me. Now, like I mentioned, there's a bunch of different maps and game modes for you to try out. I've played in multiple. My personal favorite is probably the TV station. Because it's a TV station, there's a bunch of different small vignettes built as sets throughout the station, and it creates for some really fun encounters where each individual encounter can take place in a totally different micro setting. It's It's very interesting and cool. Not to mention the tight corridors make it really, really intense when you're trying to hunt down other teams and take their loot. It's just really well executed in my opinion. It's big enough for you to get lost in and to find a bunch of new interesting stuff, but it's also intimate and tight enough in the important areas that you don't feel as though players can just run away from you and escape when you get to jump on them. They also have a limited time storm event going on right now where they take the farm map and add a ton of extra challenging things to it such as intense rain, a bunch of wind, heavy fog, reduced visibility, and the rain makes it louder so you can't hear enemies coming. It just takes all the knobs and turns them up to 11. It is much more intense. Another aspect of the game that I think is so so important in an extraction shooter or really any hardcore any type of game is that it needs to feel fair. Like it needs to feel as though when you died it's because you did something wrong or your team screwed up. Like it shouldn't feel as though the game just misbehaved. And I will give them credit. They've done a really really good job of tightening this up. Like I said, the game existed before it launched on Steam, but now that it's on Steam, a whole new wave of players are finding it, and it is just really well put together. Everything from the shooting mechanics to the movement to the inventory system and the actual builds of weapons and armor sets and everything. It's just all so robust and sturdy and well put together that it makes it feel like if somebody got to jump on you, it's your own fault. Now, personally, I think my favorite part of the game that I've encountered so far is actually the weapon building, assembly, and modification system within the gunsmith. This is basically a system you can use when you're building out your loadout to go into a match. And it allows you to either build guns using attachments you already have, or you can buy them from an in-game store where other players can sell items they've collected, or you can buy them from a merchant that the developers have basically built out for you, though that's for a higher price typically. And there is a ton of customization, whether it's the barrel that you use, the specific rail you attach your scope to, the scopes of course, suppressors, compensators, muzzles, chokes, you name it, they've got it. and it allows you to build exactly the kind of gun that you want um for your play style, which again I appreciate. And honestly, I don't really have any firm notes. Like I think it's a really wellexecuted extraction shooter and they've done a really good job. They've even directly responded to people's frustrations over like potential payto-in aspects of a game like this, which is crucial in a free-to-play game that it's not just pay to win, which is something that you can sometimes end up with in games like this. So, in response for this update, they actually removed the ability to buy the in-game currency you use to purchase gun attachments and stuff, meaning now it's just cosmetics only, which again, I think is really, really good, really healthy for the long-term life cycle of the game because it now means again when I go into an encounter, if I get jumped and get outplayed, it's because the other player just had better equipment or or was a better player probably realistically. And it was not because they just spent more money. It was because they knew what they were doing. And I'll be honest, so far that's been my experience in the game when I encounter other players. It's usually because they were posted up tactically and they were watching for me. They listened closer than I was. I wasn't paying full attention to the environment and I could have seen some indication that they had been there, like an open door, but I just wasn't thinking about it. And that's exactly what you would hope to see in a tactical extraction shooter. things that are fair, balanced, and that you could have picked up on if you had been paying more attention. One of the other things I commonly have to bring up with extraction shooters is the ability to play solo because these games can often be so dependent on other players filling out your team that one bad matchup can ruin your entire evening of playing games. Like if you grind out for hours collecting all this amazing loot and then you get matched with one random set of teammates that just are terrible, it can ruin your entire time with the game because they get you killed and you lose all of your stuff. And so having a solo queue can be really really nice because it means that you can just get in there, play by yourself. You don't have to worry about anybody else affecting it. It is just you and other solo players. And that for me is wonderful, especially if the game is balanced in a way where that can still be fun. That really makes a difference for me uh and the type of player that I am. And like I said, they have solo cues, they have duos as well in this game. And because it is free to play, you can just ask your buddies if they want to hop on with you, play around or two, and you can do that because there's no barrier to entry. title: I tried a new extraction shooter...
author: Luke Stephens
